NOTES ON THE TEXT

Inv . Coll . Co - Chruinneacha Dhan Orain &c &c . A Collection of Original Poems , Songs , &c . taken from oral recitation in various parts of the Highlands and Islands , during the last twenty years . Inverness , 1821 ( the Inverness Collection ) .
Latha bha ’ n Ridire ’ g òl
F . ‘ I had the best wife , horse , ship , dog , etc . ’ ( In M . , ‘ If I were king , I would have … ’ ) .

1 , 33 . Dha ’ n tigh mhór ,
Gesto Coll . A fhein sa te mhoir a bhean ,
M .

3 , 24 . Snagadaireachd ghearr è mhéur ,
Gesto Coll . , translated ‘ When he was carving , he cut his finger ’ in F . T . Snagaireach gun ghear e mhiar ,
M . Spadaireachd gun ghèarr e a mhiar ,
K . C . C . 46 . Cf . Dieckhoff , ‘ Snagaireachd ,
chipping with a knife ’ .

4 , 35 . This line is not in M . , which has instead
’ S nuair chunnaic e dearg a bhas = ‘ when he saw his palm was red ’ .

5 . Gesto Coll . An t - eagal a ghabh è mu mhéur ,
translated ‘ From the fear he felt about his finger ’ in F . T .

12 . The monster is said in M . to have had Da shuil dhiag air a taobh cli / Da shuil dhiag air a taobh deas ,
‘ twelve eyes on her left side , and twelve eyes on her right side ’ . Nothing more is said about her in M . , but the fragment of the ballad Collun gun Cheann printed in L . F . suggests that
21 , 48 . Marcraich is the form used in Uist and Barra for literary marcaich .

This section comes last in the Morison MS . version , and probably did not belong to the song originally . Ll . 27 – 31 here recall ll . 233 – 6 in the song on Seathan in vol . ii , see also C . G . v . 70 , last 16 lines on page , where the line Bha mi ’ n I nan cailleacha dubha leat corresponds to the line Bha mi ’ n I nan calachean ruadha of the Morison MS . version of the present song .
29 . Glasgow is not usually referred to in such flattering terms in Gaelic verse ; a more frequent appellation is Glaschu nam bùth = Glasgow of the shops .
30 . Suas means ‘ southwards ’ in Uist and Barra , as well as ‘ up ’ . The Ross of Mull must be meant here . In M . the places visited are Inverness ( twice ) , and ‘ Iona of the russet nuns ’ .

34 . In recording this song in 1949 , Miss Mary Morrison sang Gheàrr a ’ bhann - ridir ’ a meur ,
‘ the knight ’ s lady cut her finger ’ , but in 1966 according to the transcription in W . S . B . she sang Gheàrr a ’ Ridire mheur ,
which must be the correct reading , as it fits the sense of the song and is supported by all the other versions .
37 . In 1949 Miss Morrison sang a cinneadh ‘ her kin ’ , but a chàirdean ‘ his relations ’ in the next line .

41 . The metre shows that the middle vowel of dealchadh is a svarabhakti vowel that has presumably arisen since the original middle vowel was dropped through syncope . The same thing can happen in similar words , e . g . Orain Ghàidhlig le Seonaidh Caimbeul , p . 73 , where failcheadh ( from falaich ,
hide ) rhymes with margadh .
Shuidh mi air cnocan an tiùrr
MS . version : Morison MS . ( 15 lines ) . This begins Dh ’ eirich mi moch maduinn chiuin / E ho hao ri ri o hu / Shuidh mi air cnocan a ’ chiuil / E ho hao ri ri huiribh i / E ho hao ri ri o hu .

53 . This was the usual way of signalling for a ferry in the old days . The Morison MS . has Rinn mi gurraban is tùirs ’ ,
‘ I lamented and sorrowed ’ . See Gairm 81 . 95 .

Mac an Albanaich air thus
Mac an Eirionnaich mo run
Dh ’ éirich mi gu moch Di - luain
Mìle marbhaisg air a ’ ghaol

Versions of the text have been printed in the Inverness Collection of Gaelic Songs ( 1821 , p . 215 , 14 lines ; in the McD . 266 , 19 lines ; and in K . C . C . 19 , 29 lines ) . This is therefore one of the first traditional waulking song texts to have appeared in print . There has been some confusion between the text of this song and that of no . XXXIII of vol . i , which begins Cha déid mise , cha déid mi , / Cha déid mi do Cheann Loch Fraon ;
but the refrain syllables and the tunes are quite distinct . Versions of the texts of both songs can be seen side by side in K . C . C .

Gura bràthair dha ’ n aog ,
Tholl e mo chridh ’ air gach thaobh

’ S mise cheannaich e gu daor ,
Chuir e saighead ann am thaobh

111 . Inv . Coll . Cha teid mi gu Mac Iain Mhaoil , / Chan ann air a tha mo ghaol ,
‘ I will not go to the son of bald John , I do not love him ’ .
Thug mi ’ n oidhche , ge b ’ fhad ’ i

122 . Ionndrainn ‘ missing ’ in Nan MacKinnon ’ s version ( l . 158 ) makes better sense than amharc or coimhead .
The poetess could hardly have been watching the brothers in the field in the darkness of night .

123 . The MS . versions follow this line with Gum bu sin na fir allail ,
‘ Those were the famous men ’ . This was not sung by Ruairi Iain Bhàin ; if it is part of the song , the metre and rhyme suggest that a following line has been lost .

124 . Furail ,
‘ hospitable ’ , so Dieckhoff . Not in other dictionaries .

128 . D . J . McKinnon , Beidh an claibhidh sios math ruidh ,
Barra MS . , Thig an claidheamh sior - mar - ur A . J . ( 2 ) Thig an claidheamh sior ma - ribh . Siar ‘ behind ’ makes the best sense ; Ruairi Iain Bhàin apparently sang sìos .

129 . D . J . McKinnon , Nial falaish gu cul dith Barra MS . , Neall faileis gu chùl dheth A . J . ( 2 ) , ’ S neul falais gu chùl dheth .
Ruairi Iain Bhàin sang Nial falluis gu chùl air .

Agus claidheamh geur tharad , o ,
Neul fala o dhéis air .

Cf . McD . 50 , Luchd nan sgiath ’ s nan lann tana , / Neul na fala gun déis orr ’ ,
also the Turner Collection , p . 39 , ’ S neul fal ’ air roinn am picean ,
‘ The hue of blood on the points of their pikes ’ . It therefore seems justifiable to amend the line here to Nial fala gu ’ n dias air ,
which makes sense and rhyme . Cf . also McD . 215 , Bu tu sealgair na h - eala , / Bhiodh neul fal ’ air a taobh ‘ You were the hunter of the swan , there would be a hue of blood on her side ’ .
144 – 5 . The song must have been composed originally in a dialect in which deaghaidh ( pronounced deoghaidh in Barra ) and cladhach rhymed .

151 . Bucach ,
‘ a lump of a lad ’ .
Tha mo ghaol air Catriana
175 . Dwelly gives as one meaning of uinneag ‘ a recess in the wall of a kitchen used as a repository for miscellaneous articles ’ ( Sutherland ) .

O Cholla gu Rum
O Chanaidh ( ? ) do ’ n Dùn
O Uibhist a bhrùc
Gu Hirt nan eun fionn .
’ S mi ri dìreadh ’ san dùbhghlaic

194 . dùbhghlaic ,
‘ dark little glen ’ . The u is lengthened through stress falling on the first syllable of this compound word . Glaic ,
gen . for nom . glac ,
is used in Barra and Uist .

203 . This line recalls a personality frequently mentioned in old Gaelic stories , Bean chaol a ’ chòt ’ uaine ,
‘ the slender woman of the green coat ’ , a supernatural helper . Green was the colour associated with the fairies .

226 , 228 . The word circeag ,
diminutive of cearc ,
‘ hen ’ , is not in Scottish Gaelic dictionaries , but cf . Irish circín . It means ‘ hen grouse ’ in these songs .
Phiuthar chridhe , chomainn chléibh ’
The song is sung in the very unusual form of a divided line of seven syllables , divided into 4 + 3¹ .
Trom òr o chalainn , ’ s mise nach eil fallain
239 . sgire Caluim is possibly a kenning for some district in the isles .

248 . The Revd . William Matheson informs me that eàrradh is the groove inside a barrel at top and bottom into which the circular lid and bottom are fitted , and then locked into place by the hoop nearest top and bottom , called an cearcall - eàrraidh .
The spigot has to be inserted at the eàrradh to ensure that the barrel or cask can be completely emptied .

255 . Nar mheala mi ’ m bréid ,
‘ May I never live to wear the kertch ’ . Survival of a present subjunctive form . Cf . Alexander MacDonald , MS . LXIII , p . 143 :

Na no mhela mi mo bhrecan
Muile mhaon mar sin smo phersa ,
Mar heil mi toilich an iobra ncertuair
Ann abhir an riogh sa chertis
The bréid or kertch was worn by women after marriage in the old Highlands .

257 . Beannag .
Cf . Alexander Carmichael , C . G . v . 12 . ‘ A small shawl [formerly] worn by women in Uist , sometimes on the shoulders and sometimes on the head … In the early half of the nineteenth century

all young women in Uist put up the beannag on the morning of their wedding . This was of white linen formed into thin broad bands or hems from the forehead to the crown of the head . This was the badge of marriage . ’ Ll . 256 and 257 therefore are the equivalent of saying ‘ May I never be married ’ .

270 – 1 . i . e . collecting seaweed used for manure , used on the feannagan or lazy - beds , the digging of which was described by Martin Martin , A Description of the Western Islands of Scotland , 1716 edn . , p . 3 . Cf . Fr . Allan McDonald , ‘ the special work in making lazy beds called taomadh is the filling of the hollow between the row of sods on the outer edge of each lazy bed with soil taken from the drain or trench at each side of each bed — a drain formed by the removal of the sods already mentioned ’ ( G . W . S . U . 236 ) .
Lìon mulad , lìon mulad

282 . Mrs MacPhee used the form aotrom ,
which does not rhyme , suggesting that the song was originally made in a dialect where eutrom was the normal pronunciation . Mrs . McInnis , whose father ’ s people were of South Uist origin and whose mother ’ s were from Barra , had eutrom .
283 . Mrs . McInnis had Nàile ! goirtead mo choise .

295 . Cf . the proverb Uaisle gun chuid , maragan gun gheir ,
‘ Gentry without goods , sausages without fat ’ .
Gura mise tha gu tinn

312 . The line following this one was inadvertently omitted in transcribing . It is Cha do dh ’ fhoighneachd , cha b ’ fhiach ,
‘ He didn ’ t ask ( the price ) , he didn ’ t need to ’ .
330 . Cf . Dinneen , scuabach ‘ in sweeping masses ( of the hair ) ’ ( amongst other meanings ) ; R . I . A . Contrib . , scúap , sense ( e ) , referring to human hair .
Tha mulad , tha mulad

378 . Coir ’ a ’ Cheathaich ,
the Misty Corrie , in the Forest of Mamlorn , north of Crianlarich , the subject of a famous poem by Duncan Ban MacIntyre . This is evidence of a mainland origin for this song .
Mhurchaidh bhig , a chinn a ’ chonais

Printed versions ; K . C . C . 95 , 35 lines , of which eleven on the formulaic motif ‘ if I were dividing the land you would get … ’ seem quite out of place . C . G . iv . 350 , three quatrains of the form ABCD + DEFG + GHIJ , with translation , in the section of the book headed ‘ Miscellaneous ’ , source not stated . The first 6 lines correspond very closely to ll . 401 – 5 , 415 – 17 , and 451 – 5 here . This indicates that at least part of the present song was not originally a waulking song .
398 , 433 , 464 . Bran = Bran mac Febail ? Brian probably = Brian Boroimhe , victor of the battle of Clontarf , whose name occurs in some Scottish Gaelic folktales .

400 . In the version recorded on 2 / 11 / 50 , this line was followed by Le each crùidheach cròinfhionn soilleir ,
‘ with his bright well - shod white - haired horse ’ .

412 , 421 . Is minig is used in Uist with the sense of Is mairg ,
‘ Pity he who ’ , not with its usual meaning of ‘ often ’ , which is the one that fits the sense here , suggesting that the song was originally made in a district where minig usually had that meaning .

417 . The singer here had Marcraich ’ sìdhneadh nan each seang ,
a line which does not make sense , and which was probably due to the confusion of two such lines as Marcraich ’ nan steud crùidheach seang , / Sealgair sìdhneadh nan damh donn ,
‘ Rider of slender well - shod steeds , Hunter of venison of the red deer ’ . Cf . l . 905 in vol . i .

461 . ‘ It was the custom with the bullies… to demand a cess from the country , to which every gentleman and commoner was to contribute , unless the Laird could find a person who was able to defy them with the sword . ’ W . C . MacKenzie , The Western Isles , p . 130 . See Stories from South Uist , p . 92 . See also T . G . S . I . xxxix - xl . 163 – 5 .
Mhic Iarla nam Bratach Bàna

474 . A . J . sithinn .
The word sounds like si on the record , and Capt . MacKinnon writes shi . Metrically it must be only one syllable .

476 . The rhyming of stàtail / airgid / bàineadh and later of sàile / airgid / Gailmhinn / Spàine is an unusual phenomenon . Commonly words containing a svarabhakti vowel require similar words for rhyme , but as John MacDonald , M . A . , has pointed out , sometimes words containing a long vowel or diphthong can be used instead . Instances in the poems of Rob Donn and Lain Lom are referred to ( S . G . S . ii . 73 ) . In the Fernaig MS . , folbh rhymes with òl and with thòs ( M . MacFarlane , ed . , pp . 263 , 273 ) .

481 , 482 . Cf . the version of An Fhìdeag Airgid printed by Ella Carmichael in the Celtic Review , i . 147 , Air luing riomhaich nam ball airgid , / Le stiuir oir is da chrann airgid , / ’ S cupuill oirr ’ de shiod na Gailbhein .
See also ll . 1737 – 40 , here .
Ciad soiridh bhuam dhachaigh
A Mhic Iain ’ ic Sheumais

The Revd . John MacDonald must have been an active collector of Gaelic oral tradition . He contributed seventeen poems to K . , of which seven were of his own composition ; of these seventeen , nine appear in McD . Of the battle of Carinish , the Revd . John MacDonald told Captain Thomas that he ‘ had not lost an opportunity of getting information regarding it for the last twenty years . I gathered it from the most trustworthy people in Uist ; with some of these I have walked over the ground and had the plan of battle pointed out and explained to me . One of them gave me the account as he had it from his grandfather , who was a native of Carinish … he was accounted the best sennachie of his day . In fact , while I may say I have heard the account fifty or a hundred times , I have never heard it with any material difference . ’ ( 1 )

‘ The upshot of these tactics was that the fight was reduced to one on level terms , in which the MacDonalds were victorious . Only five or six of the MacLeods escaped ; Dòmhnall Glas was killed on a strand of Baleshare Island , which has ever since been called after him ; his skull , distinguished by a sword gash , remained in a window of Teampull na Trianaid for many years . Towards the end of the fight Dòmhnall mac Iain ’ ic Sheumais getting to close quarters with the enemy , had “ received an arrow ann am beul a ’ chuarain ” ,
i . e . at the mouth of his cuaran or shoe , which threw him on his length in “ Féithe na fala ” . . . .

“ Mhic Iain , a laoidh mo chéilleadh
Gur moch a chuala tu ’ n éibhe , ” &c .

Erskine Beveridge says that it is understood that Dòmhnall mac Iain ’ ic Sheumais later settled at Carinish . ‘ His descendants continued to occupy Eriskay … for several generations , and it was in the house of this Donald ’ s great - great - grandson — Angus MacDonald , tacksman of Eriskay in 1745 — that Prince Charles Edward spent his first night on Scottish soil after disembarking from the Doutelle . ’

K . C . C .

538 . Dh ’ fhas na speuran salach A . C . ; Dh ’ fhàs na reultan salach K . C . C . ; ’ S bha na reulta galach Òr . , G . ; ’ S bha na reultan ’ gam falach F . T . ; ’ S bha na reultan salach K . , Mrs . McCormick .
543 . Mu Mhac Òr . ; ’ S è Mac F . T .

551 . Rìgh Leòdhais = MacLeod of Lewis . Dòmhnall ’ s paternal great grandmother was a MacLeod of Lewis ( Clan Donald , iii . 469 ) .
556 . Sìol Ailein mac Ruairidh = the MacDonalds of Clanranald . Dòmhnall mac Iain ’ ic Sheumais ’ s mother belonged to this branch of the clan ( Clan Donald , iii . 500 ) .
Ach a Mhaighread nan cuiread

Other printed versions : the poem Fleasgach a ’ Bhadain , printed by D . C . MacPherson on pp . 132 – 3 of his Duanaire contains 5 couplets that are usually associated with this song ( D . C . M . 55 – 6 ) , although the metre in this case is 6² + 6² , not 6² + 5¹ . The couplets correspond to lines , 565 – 6 , 569 – 70 , 561 – 2 , and 567 – 8 here , in that order .

570 . Following this couplet , Mrs . Angus John MacLellan has Cha tog fidheall no clàrsach no pìob àrd air deagh - ghleus ,
‘ Neither fiddle nor harp will lift it , nor the tall well - tuned pipes ’ .

591 . Cf . the first couplet of no . CVI . In K . this couplet ’ s equivalent is followed by Le ghunn ’ air a ghuallain Dol gu buaille ( sic ) Mhic Neill ,
‘ With his gun on his shouldier . Going to the cattlefold of MacNeil ’ ( of Barra , presumably ) .

641 . Canon MacLean , ’ S tìr mór a cuir smala , mnathan geala ’ cuir ghleus .
K . C . C . Teine mór a ’ cur smala ’ s mnathan geala cur gleus .
Mrs . A . J . MacLellan , Teine mór a ’ cur smal dheth ’ s mnathan geal ’ a ’ cur gréis . A ’ cur gréis ‘ embroidering ’ seems to make better sense than a ’ cur gleus ‘ putting in order ’ .
Thogainn fonn gun bhith trom

‘ It was when he ( i . e . Dòmhnall Donn ) lifted a spoil in Caithness that he made the song Thogainn fonn gun bhith trom ,
and what happened was that he lifted the “ brown - haired girl ” along with the spoil ( of cattle ) . He had a companion with him called Lachuinn , and it seems that Lachuinn fell for the girl just as much as Dòmhnall Donn did . Lachuinn wanted to have the girl for himself , and he agreed that Dòmhnall Donn should have the entire spoil , if he got the girl . Dòmhnall Donn agreed to this ; but the girl got an opportunity to escape from the inn where they were stopping for the night on the way home , for they were tired and sleepy . He ( Lachuinn ) lost both ways ; he lost the girl and he lost the cattle . ’

K . C . Craig has a version of 46 lines from Màiri nighean Alasdair ( p . 63 ) . But the fact that a version of this song was printed ( p . 118 ) , as long ago as 1786 in the Gillies Collection has been overlooked . This is headed simply ‘ North Highland Airs , No . 40 ’ , referring to Patrick MacDonald ’ s Collection of Vocal Highland Airs , published in about 1780 , where the air is titled
‘ Tha fonn gun bhi trom — I am disposed to mirth . ’ But this is a different song , as the Revd . William Matheson has pointed out to me ; the ascription of the tune by Gillies to the present song is an error . In the Gillies Collection it has 5 quatrains with a 4 - line refrain , all of which correspond closely to similar verses and refrains in the MacLean Sinclair and A . MacDonald versions .

It is to be noted that in all the mainland and Nova Scotian versions the song is set out in quatrains with a 4 - line refrain of which the first 2 lines correspond to the 2 - line refrain here , and the third and fourth are versions of the last couplet but two in K . C . C . , e . g . Colin Chisholm , Gruagach òg a ’ chùil duinn , Dh ’ éireadh fonn orm ri t ’ fhaicinn .
This also suggests very strongly that the song was not originally sung as a waulking song , and that the air to which it is sung in South Uist is not the original air .

670 . K . C . C . , aodail ;
A . M . S . , ’ n fhaodail ,
so C . C . ; Penny Morrison aoibh gheal ,

694 . K . C . C . Loch Carthann ;
A . M . S . , McD . , Lochabar .

699 . K . C . C . air a ’ chàrn ;
A . M . S . , McD . , air a ’ chàl .

706 . Penny Morrison has the additional couplet , of which a version is also found in K . C . C . , Liom a ’ chuibheall , liom an càrd , Liom a ’ bhrà , liom a ’ bhratach ,
‘ Mine the spinning - wheel , mine the wool - card , mine the quern , mine the banner ’ , referring to the reiver ’ s booty . For bratach K . C . C . has craiceann ,
‘ hide ’ .
Dh ’ fhalbh mo rùn bho chionn seachdain

Bhigh an ruadhag sa ghlaoich ,
Aig mo ghaolsa na bhreachan .

In K . this is
Bhiodh an ruaghag ’ s a ghlaodhaich ,
Aig mo ghaolsa fo bhreacan .

which presumably would mean ‘ my love would have the roe deer and its cry beneath his plaid ’ . The corresponding couplet in the version preserved by Dr . Calum MacLean shows that the ghlaoich of E . is a misprint for laogh aic ’ ,
and that the meaning is ‘ the roe deer and her fawn ’ .

Bha do chairdeas gu direach
Ris na Rioghridh bh ’ air sasunn .

756 . E . , K . , and the version printed in Bàrdachd Shìlis na Ceapaich all have Shìol Ailpein ,
i . e . descendants of Kenneth MacAlpine , progenitor of Scottish kings . A number of small clans claimed this status , particularly the MacGregors .

762 . Martin Martin says that ‘ The Natives call this Isle [i . e . Canna] by the Name of Tarsin at Sea ’ ( cf . l . 722 ) . The name was probably bestowed because the island lies east and west . Nominally church land , it was occupied by the MacDonalds of Clanranald . In the present couplet E . has eillannainuibh farising ( sic ) ‘ far - flung islands ’ ; K . likewise ; Bàrdachd Shìlis na Ceapaich , nan eileanan fada ‘ of the long islands ’ . This would date the poem to after the acquisition of Lewis by the MacKenzies , which took place in 1610 . Mr . Fred MacAulay , Senior Gaelic Producer of the B . B . C . , who is from North Uist , informs me that the tradition in his family is that they originally came from Na h - Eileanan Tarsuinn ,
which he was told in Benbecula , referred to Coll and Tiree .
Chunnaic mi an t - òg uasal

786 . C . J . , ialdag ,
‘ bat ’ .
793 . C . J . , sgorrlach ( not in dictionaries and not rhyming ) .

801 . C . J . , Nuair a rachadh i seachad / Sgaoilte mach e ri grein .

805 . C . J . , Gun bhi creidsinn nan gillean / Air cho milis am beul ,

O , daonnan tha mi deònach
Dh ’ fhalbh mo rùn ’ s dh ’ fhàg e ’ n caladh

so pronounced . Cf . Dwelly , p . 77 , tobhta amar .
The Barra MS . has tobhta tarruing .

877 . Mac Fhir Locha Mhùideart ,
the son of MacDonald of Kinlochmoidart . The family was a branch of the Clanranalds , Jacobites whose representatives fought at Killiecrankie , Sheriffmuir , and Culloden .

879 . Mac Fhionghuin a ’ chléirich may be a corruption of Mac Fhionghuin a ’ Chréithich referred to elsewhere , cf . vol . ii , l . 141 , and K . C . C . 44 , ‘ Mac Fhionghainn o ’ n Chréithich ’ .
MacKinnon of Strath in Skye .

Calievers , not culverins . See Éigse , ii . 44 .
883 . Mac ’ ic Dhùbhghaill is the patronymic of the MacDonalds of Morar , another branch of the Clanranalds .

O , mo nighean dubh , till , till

Òganaich ùir a ’ chùil teudaich ,

O hùgaibh , hùg a ri hug ,
Hùg air clò mhic ’ ille Mhìcheil .

which does not rhyme .

928 . Alexander MacDonald , fifth earl of Antrim . His forebear had sent Alasdair Mac Colla with his army to help Montrose in 1644 . His horses are also mentioned in Ais - eiridh , p . 102 , Antram lu ’ - chleasach na ’ n seang - each .

931 . The MacLeans . The absence of any internal rhyme from this couplet suggests that there has been a mistake in copying here at some time , and that the first line of one couplet has been combined with the second line of a following one . Spuaghail is written in Ella Carmichael ’ s version as an alternative to luadhadh .

Thig bannal a nall a Cataobh ,
’ S bheir iad caitein air mu ’ n till iad ,

S ioma Cló air ’ n tug iad caittein ,
Eadar Cattamh , agus Anuinn .

‘ The least drop of mercy / which God of verity ordered / Is not in the breast of the Butcher / George ’ s son by the harlot . ’
’ S muladach , ’ s muladach , thà mi

Thog sinn oirnn gu tighinn dha ’ n dùthaich ,
Bha ’ n ceò dùmhail air na beannan .

1005 – 10 . Cf . Òran Cuartachaidh ,

O hao , O hao , ’ s mì fo mhìngean

On 18 March 1949 , the late Monsignor P . J . Nicholson , President of St . Francis Xavier University , Antigonish , Nova Scotia , sent me a MS . version communicated to him by James H . MacNeil , of Sydney , but formerly of Iona , Cape Breton , who had received it from Mr . Joseph MacKinnon , also of Sydney . This also contains 14 couplets ( plus one repeated ) . Mr . Joseph MacKinnon wrote that ‘ It [the song] has been kept up at Rear Big Pond , and at Glen Garry , Cape Breton , since ever my two great grandmothers , brought it over from Barra , some century and a quarter back ’ — i . e . around 1825 .

Gu ’ m bu slàn gu ’ n till an t - òigear
Bha ’ n coill nan cnò ’ ga gearradh ,

’ S mairg san am sin chuireadh greann air ,
Thogail angair an fhir ruaidh
1015 . Eala Bhàn is not capitalized in K . C . C . , the only other context , but surely it must be the name of the boat .

1029 . Nan gartan rìomhach .
This implies that he had female admirers , see note to l . 733 .

1053 . Di - Sathuirne .
Various days are assigned for the start of the voyage . The Morison MS . has ‘ Saturday ’ ; D . C . MacPherson has ‘ Monday ’ ; and Sgeulaiche nan Caol , ‘ Tuesday ’ .

1069 . Rubh ’ an Àilein .
The Morison MS . has Ruth - an - fhasaich ;
neither has been identified . On this voyage , one would expect Rubh ’ Àrasaig ,
the Point of Arisaig .

1073 . Morison MS . Dol seachad a ’ n Carn bha sgriob aic ’ ,
cf . Sgrìob in Fr . Allan McDonald ’ s Gaelic words from South Uist ( ‘ sailing on the same tack ’ ) . Sgeulaiche nan Caol has Dol seachad an Càrn ’ na sìnteig ,
‘ at speed ’ . The Càrn is the rocks north of Coll known in English as the Cairns of Coll .

Dol seachad an linne sleibhteach
Shil is sheid i le cloich mheallain

1084 . Morison MS . , ’ M bial Loch - Roaig .
So Sgeulaiche nan Caol . The name Croic is not in Forbes ’ s book referred to above . Roag in Skye is at the head of the western branch of Loch Bracadale . Following this verse , Sgeulaiche nan Caol has the couplet Gu ’ m bu slàn do ’ n t - saor a dh ’ fhuaigh i , / Làmh a ’ chruadail dh ’ fhuaigh a darach ,
‘ A health to the carpenter who made her , / Hardy hand that seamed her oak ’ .

1085 . The Morison MS . has Thainig soills ’ oirnn ’ bho ’ n Ghealaich ,
‘ Light came on us from the moon ’ . Cf . ll . 992 , 1030 .

1089 – 90 . The Morison MS . has Leag sinn air corsa direach / Air tir iosal Mhic - ic - Ailein ,
‘ We laid our course straight for the low country of Clanranald ’ . This was presumably South Uist ; the Clanranald land they passed was Canna .

Chuir sinn acair air gach taobh dhi
’ S gu ’ n d ’ thug fear mo ghaoil dh ’ uinn drama .
A Dhòmhnaill Dhuinn , ma rinn thu m ’ eugcoir

No other versions are known to us , though D . C . M . contains a love song of 15 couplets made to the same refrain , p . 124 , beginning Gur a mis a ta fo mhulad / ’ S mi ’ m shuidhe air uilinn nan àrd .

In Barra this song was known as Cumha Bhanntrach Shanndraidh ,
the Lament of the Sandray Widow ( Sandray is a small island south of Barra , now uninhabited ) . The story was that she had made the song to lament her three sons being taken by the press - gang at the time of the Napoleonic wars . There are difficulties about this , involving the possible identity of ‘ Dòmhnall Donn ’ and the fact that the leaders of press - gangs were not in the habit of handing out guineas ( first coined in 1663 ) to the parents of the young men whom they took .

1095 . K . C . C . and G . S . N . S . have Dhòmhnaill Ghuirm for Dhòmhnaill Dhuinn .
Nan MacKinnon has Dhòmhnaill Uilleim .
Fr . Allan McDonald has Dhònuill Ghuirm ,
preceded by the note that ‘ Donull Gorm Clanranald is always mentioned with feelings of horror . The following stanza is from a song composed by a widow whose every son he [MS . she] took away from her ’ .

‘ Donald Gorme was also blamed for not having gone with his contingent of 20 men to aid his brother in his time of need . Men shook their heads and looked wise when they stated that Donald himself succeeded to his brother ’ s property and position … There is a cairn called Carn Dhomhnuill Ghuirm ,
which points out the scene of an irregular and bloody action , and where Donald is said to have sat watching the fight when he should have come to his brother ’ s aid . ’ ( Clan Donald , ii . 301 – 2 ; the authors give Farquhar Beaton , shepherd at Drimsdale , South Uist , as the source of the latter tradition . )

1107 . The seventh and tenth couplets of Mrs . MacNeil ’ s version are not found in the G . S . N . S . version , nor are the sixth , seventh , tenth , and eleventh of Mrs . MacInnes ’ s . On the other hand , the G . S . N . S . version has 6 couplets that are not found in these versions , though the equivalent of one of them is the sixth in Nan MacKinnon ’ s version . This , which comes after a gap in the recording , is Nach fhaic mi tighinn an t - eithear / Air nach fhaicear fear fo ràimh .
The G . S . N . S . version suggests that ’ S truagh at the beginning has not been recorded , if so , the translation would be ‘ A pity I don ’ t see the boat coming , on which a man at the oar is not seen . ’

1113 . The words on the recording are Gura mise tha fo mhulad ,
but this does not rhyme . Miss Annie Johnston informed me that the correct reading should be as given here .

1129 . Dosrach is uncertain , but seems to be the word that fits the sense here . Feadan ( in the plural ) appears to be used here and in other similar contexts to include all the hollow tubes that make up a set of bagpipes , not just the chanter .
Gur h - e mo ghille dùbhdhonn
Chunnaic mise mo leannan

Printed versions : Gillies Collection , 1786 , p . 245 ( 9 couplets ) ; T . G . S . I . viii . 115 , in paper on ‘ Leaves from my Celtic Portfolio IV ’ read by William MacKenzie on 7 / 5 / 1879 , taken down ‘ from an old woman on Skye ’ , 14 couplets ; Òranaiche , 1879 , p . 504 ( 17 couplets ) ; C . G . ii 299 ( 1900 ) , 5 couplets from a version ‘ taken down from an old woman in Uist in 1866 . She said that the song had been composed to one of the gallant Clanranalds by a lady , after the battle of Auldearn ’ . ( The 5 couplets are quoted in the Notes to the first two volumes of C . G . to illustrate the term còta gearr .
) T . G . S . I . xxvi . 241 ( 20 couplets ) , no ascription , in a paper by the Revd . A . MacLean Sinclair , read on 23 / 11 / 1905 , entitled ‘ A Collection of Gaelic Poems ’ ; McD . 49 , identical with K . , but adding 2 more couplets in the description of the song in the list of contents ; K . C . C . ( 1949 ) , to couplets .

Thug sibh mionnan a Bhiobail ,
Ann srath iosal uilt - eirinn

Charles or James ? The battle of Auldearn , between Inverness and Elgin , was fought on 8 May 1645 , and was one of Montrose ’ s most brilliant victories ; his Highland lieutenant , Alasdair mac Colla ( see vol . ii , no . LXXI ) performed prodigies of valour at it . But King Charles was already a crowned king when it was fought , and the couplet could only make sense if the word crùinte ( adh )
were translated ‘ restored ’ . The allusion could be to something that had happened in the past .

Opening couplets : T . G . S . I . viii , Òranaiche , F . F . S . U . , and G . S . N . S . have the same opening couplet as Catriana Campbell , ll . 1190 – 1 here . See also the eleventh couplet in the song Fleasgach a ’ Bhadain , D . C . M . , p . 133 . In T . G . S . I . viii and in G . S . N . S . this is followed by Mi na m ’ laidhe ann an Crosal ’ S trom an osn ’ tha fo m ’ leine ( G . S . N . S . has
’ g a m ’ léireadh for fo m ’ leine ) . Crosal is in Skye , between Sligachan and Drynoch , in the MacLeod country ; it is very unlikely that a MacLeod woman would have made a song lavishing such praise on the MacDonalds as this one does .

1191 – 2 . In Gillies alone , the corresponding couplet is Cha b ( ’ ) ann aige bha choire , Ach nach d ’ fhuirich mi fhein ris .
‘ It was not his fault , but that I did not wait for him . ’

Gillies : Gu ’ n cinnich an Domhnach

‘ would send arrows flying ’ , Gillies , T . G . S . I . viii , K . , McD . , G . S . N . S . , is better . K . C . C . has Chuireadh fiughair fo shaighdean .

Dùbladh ‘ sheathe ’ , a rare word in Scottish Gaelic , is probably the right reading when the rhyme is with crùinte .

1207 . This couplet is missing from the Gillies , Òranaiche , C . G . , K . C . C . , F . F . S . U . , and G . S . N . S . versions . K . and McD . , where one might expect to find it , have Gu ma slàn do na gillean / Dh ’ fhalbh le iomairt Righ Seurlas ‘ Here a health to the lads / who went away on the expedition of King Charles ’ . Actual variants : T . G . S . I . viii , Gus an deanta Righ Seoras / A ’ ròiceadh ’ s a reubadh .
Morison MS . , Gan faicinn Righ Deorsa / Na spolan bho cheile .
Barra MS . , Gus a toirte Righ Deorsa / Air a spoltadh ’ o cheile .
T . G . S . I . xxvi , ’ S gus am faict ’ a luchd - fògraidh / ’ Dol ’ s na còrdaibh na ’ éirig .

Cha n - ioghnadh do mhàthair
Bhith cràiteach mu d ’ dhéidhinn ;

( 8 ) Tha sac trom air mo chridhe
Cha tog fidheal na ’ n teud e
( 9 ) Cha tog fidheal na clarsach
Piob no taileasg na dheigh e

Ged robh Paruig ga gleusadh
1263 . Morison MS . bothag na th ’ airidh ( sic ) .

1265 – 6 . This couplet is from the Morison MS . The singer , who appeared to be uncertain of the words here , apparently had Ann am bothag mi gun dh ’ fhiadhaich , / Far nach bu mhiann ri tòir ach éiginn ,
which does not make very good sense , and is unmetrical in the second line .
Gura mis ’ tha fo mhulad , tha lionn - dubh air mo lìonadh
1287 – 90 . Compare the fifth and seventh couplets of the song beginning Chì mi am bàta a ’ dol seachad in T . G . S . I . xxxix – xl . 188 , which has the same refrain as no . CXX here .
Gura mise tha fo mhulad an tìr a ’ mhurain ’ s an t - sìobain

‘ Archibald MacLean of Heisker , the hero of this song and of a number of others , was engaged to be married to Susan MacDonald , Vallay [an island off the north side of North Uist] but he left her . Her brother , Alexander , who was factor of North Uist , became very oppressive to the gay Lothaire , and leaving the country he was never heard of again . The composer of the song was Anna Macdonald ( nighean Dòmhnaill Oig ) who lived at Balranald , N . Uist ’ ( p . 39 ) . In McD . note on this song ( p . xxiv ) it is stated that Anna Macdonald was Archibald MacLean ’ s foster - sister .

There is another song to Archibald MacLean , Tha Fear Heisgir a ’ tighinn / Bu tu ceann - uidhe nan ciad ( K . p . 127 ; McD . 199 ; From the Farthest Hebrides pp . 48 – 52 ) . This is said to have been made by Rachel Macdonald ( Raonaid nighean ’ ic Néill ) , Grenitote , North Uist , whose dates are given as c . 1750 – 1820 . This , together with the reference in McD . and F . T . versions to Archibald MacLean ’ s kelp being unmade and unavailable for export to England , would put the date of the song at around 1775 .

McD . says in the notes on this song ( p . xxiii ) that ‘ This song is in praise of Archibald MacLean of Heisker , in North Uist . His powers as a steersman and the seaworthy qualities of his galley are powerfully depicted . Archibald was a son of Iain mac Ghilleasbuig Oig of Heisker , of the family of Boreray [cf . no . CXI in this vol . ] . He was at this time tacksman of Heisker and Steelbow tenant of Peinmore , now part of Balranald . He emigrated to Canada , and died at Ontario in the early part of last century . ’

The cause of his troubles is alluded to in a couplet found in the K . , McD . , and K . C . C . versions ; Their gach neach air am beag e Gur e ’ m beadradh a mhill e .
‘ Everyone who dislikes him says that it is flirting that ruined him . ’ In consequence of his breach of promise , he has had to leave North Uist ( testimony to the power of factors in the eighteenth century ) , and his affairs are in a ruinous condition : his buildings have lost their thatch , his boat is pulled up unused on the shore , his barley is unreaped , his peat is unmade , his kelp has not been cut , and his cattle are unherded . The picture is vivid and convincing .

1316 . Tìr a ’ mhurain ,
‘ the land of bent - grass ’ , is a kenning for Uist , referring to the bent - grass that grows freely on the sandhills of the machair there .

1324 . K . , McD . , and K . C . C . have do bhràithrean ’ s na h - Innsibh ,
‘ your brothers are in the Indies ’ . The couplet is not in F . T .

1334 . This couplet was followed by an eleventh of which the transcription is uncertain . It could be something like Làmh riachaid nan searrag Miosg nam fear air a ’ phìthir ( ? )
The other versions give no help here . The fourth and eighth couplets of Mrs . Monk ’ s version are also not found in any of the others .
’ S ’ ga innse cha déid mi
’ Ille dhuinn bhòidhich

Printed versions : text alone , Duanaire . ( 1868 ) , p . 68 , ( 16 couplets : headed An Gille Donn and signed Muileach ) ; Òranaiche , ( 1879 ) , p . 456 ( 16 couplets , identical with Duanaire , except that Òr . has deònach for D . C . M . dòineach in seventh couplet ) ; Mac - Talla , vi . 64 ( 1897 , 23 couplets ) ; K . C . C . ( 1949 ) , p . 49 ( 26 couplets , of which three in praise of the Clan Donald probably do not originally belong to the song ) .

The M . T . version is headed ‘ Duanag le Saighdear Muileach ’ , and is signed ‘ Gleann - a - Bhaird ’ ( ? = MacLean Sinclair ) . The refrain here is O ho rò , a nigh ’ n donn , / A nigh ’ n donn bhoidheach , O ho rò , a nigh ’ n donn .

A waulking song in the Morison MS . beginning Ailein duinn a ’ chùil duallaich , / Cha robh buaidh air do sheòrsa is given as sung to the refrain Hiri horo Ailein duinn / Ailein duinn bhòidhich / Hi ri ho ro Ailein duinn ,
which may very well indicate a version of this air , as the song here is also connected with the island of Mull .

’ S bheir mi mollachd air gillean
… rithist mo dhòigh - sa
‘ My curse on lads … He is often in the inn , my hands would be in my pockets ; he would be draining the glass , being a silly fool . ’

1344 . Killin Collection culaidh ,
‘ equipment ’ , an obvious attempt to get rid of an English loan - word , for the Killin text , apart from couplets omitted , is the same as that of the Òranaiche .

1358 . K . C . C . following the corresponding couplet , has one referring to their sailing to the Indies , from where they would not return alive : the corresponding couplet in Mrs . Johnston ’ s version is Ach gu stràid nan ceum dìreach / Far nach till sinn ri ’ r beò as ,
‘ but to the street of straight footsteps , whence we shall not return alive ’ . The Indies are not mentioned there or in any other version .

Òr . , deònach .

It is likely that Duanaire and M . T . are right here .

Other versions : the only one we have been able to find is the text printed in K . C . C . 54 ( 23 couplets ) . This begins with the couplet Gura mise tha fo mhulad / ’ S mi air uilinn nam fuarbheann ,
and the refrain reverses that recorded here ( bab for aba ) , a matter also commented on by the late Duncan Macdonald the famous South Uist Gaelic storyteller . The impression given by the text in K . C . C . is one of confusion . Couplets 5 – 8 as sung by Mrs . D . J . MacLellan occur in K . C . C . as couplets 21 – 3 ; couplets 9 and 11 as couplets 12 and 16 in K . C . C . There is no further correspondence .
O , ’ s toil liom an nìghneag

1445 . ’ s toil lium is usually written
’ s toigh lium ,
but it is easy to confirm the word used in speech , by asking such a question as an toil libh ìm ?
‘ Do you like butter ? ’ to which the answer will be
’ s toil ,
not
’ s toigh .
Alexander MacDonald wrote toil ,

1486 , 1524 . Literally ‘ Lies will be growing along with him ’ . Shoemakers had the reputation in the Highlands of being untruthful because the shoes they were making or mending were said never to be ready on the day they were promised . The late Seonaidh Caimbeul the South Lochboisdale bard said of them Tha ch - uile h - aon cho briagach dhiubh / Gu sgialachdan do chàch ‘ Every one of them is so untruthful , for telling stories to everyone else ’ ( Orain , p . 61 ) .
1508 , 1510 . These lines illustrate the different meanings of the word fàsach .
1514 . Taking truimeir to be a borrowing of the English word ‘ strummer ’ .
1518 . The implication is that he would be fonder of his fiddle than of his wife . In Gaelic , a musical instrument is referred to as the céile ‘ spouse ’ , of its player .

1680 . Peas and beans were an important crop in Scotland in old times , before the introduction of the potato . An Act of the Scots Parliament of James I ordained that ‘ each man tilling with a plough of eight oxen shall sow at least each year a firlot of wheat , half a firlot [ = a quarter of a boll] of peas , and xl beans , under pain of x shillings to the baron of the land that he dwells in , as often as he be found guilty . ’ The baron was bound to do the same planting under penalty of 40 shillings payable to the king . See Hume Brown , Scotland before 1700 , p . 23 . Cf . vol . i , l . 1063 ; vol . ii , l . 1028 .
Thug an latha gu dìle

1697 . In a letter to Francis Collinson , Nan MacKinnon explained tomanan meala as ‘ tufts of earth where the bees have their hives in tufts of tall grass ’ . Bumble - bees are meant . C . R . and K . C . C . have croinn mhealadh .

1752 . Treas - tarraing was three times distilled whisky , see l . 1431 in vol . ii and note thereon .

1753 . The appellation o Ghallaibh ,
which would normally mean ‘ from Caithness ’ , is puzzling . Brandy was not imported into the Highlands and islands via Caithness . One might suspect a corruption of o Ghaillimh ,
‘ from Galway ’ ( in Ireland ) . Galway is mentioned in Scottish Gaelic verse as a source of silk ( l . 452 , here ) , linen ( l . 1242 in vol . i ) , and wax ( Bàrdachd Ghàidhlig l . 6341 ) , in these instances always in the oblique form Gailmhinn or Gailbhinn .
In any case , the pronunciation is different . In the W . S . B . transcription of Ceit Ruairi Iain Bhàin ’ s version of the song , the word is given as Cailidh and translated ‘ Calais ’ . This is not supported by any other version known to us , and seems unlikely . Calais was not a port from which wine and brandy were shipped to the Highlands . In the circumstances , I have translated o Ghallaibh by ‘ from abroad ’ .

1754 . In Ella Carmichael ’ s version this line has cadhan ,

This is unlikely . Càrnan must be the right word .
1762 . Mo sgian lìth in a version corrected by Miss Annie Johnston . But chlì seems clear on the recording involved .
‘ Alas ’ seems the most appropriate translation of Mo cheist in this context ; cf . Irish ( Dinneen ) .

Mo ghaol am ministeir ainmeil
Cha be mac sin tu Fearachar
Cha be ogha Mairi Simason

Simason presumably = Jamieson , but there is no such name to be found in the lists of the clergy , Protestant or Catholic , of South Uist or Barra . There were Jamiesons in Canna before the Clearances : there are seven in the 1820 rent - roll .

1283 . Sobhal na slataich is a barn made with sides of wicker - work . The massacre in the Eigg cave was also mentioned by Dr . Johnson in A Journey to the Western Islands of Scotland , 1775 , p . 154 , and by John Leyden in his Journal of a Tour in the Highlands and Western Islands of Scotland in 1800 in a letter written to Sir Walter Scott on 27 August of that year . Leyden said that ‘ Having procured candles , we began with the cave of the massacre , the most easterly of those on the south side of the island . The entrance is low , narrow , and irregular , and we were obliged to enter on all - fours . Before we could stand erect we found we were creeping over dead men ’ s bones . The cave then becomes more spacious and lofty … It extends in length about a hundred paces , and through its whole extent is strewed with bones ’ ( pp . 155 – 6 ) .

812 . The sound referred to is that between North Uist and the small island of Rona which lies to the south - east of North Uist . The Revd . W . Matheson tells me that in the days of sail it was an important roadstead , known as Seòlaid Rubha Eubhadh .
964 . for ‘ strath ’ read ‘ stream ’ . Struth is clear in the MS .

Epilogue , last paragraph but one : it is uncertain whether the reciter said asad or orst ;
it sounds more like asad . This implies that by throwing the cogie or wooden bowl with some food in it and hitting her stepdaughter with it , the stepmother had removed the spells the fairy lover had put on her stepdaughter .

1122 . Gachdan air òl .
In an undated letter to me written a considerable number of years ago , in Gaelic , Miss Annie Johnston wrote that it was more than twenty years since she had taken down the words of this song from an old lady long since dead . She had not known the word gachdan at the time , but understood that it meant slugadh sìos deoch làidir ann an cabhaig ,
‘ drinking down strong drink in a hurry ’ . Perhaps it could have been glocan air òl .

The Revd . W . Matheson draws my attention to the fact that there is another line after 1260 on the Linguaphone record of this song , Bealach a ’ Sgail ’ s cha n - e fantail ,
‘ to put behind us yonder pass , Bealach a ’ Sgail , and not to wait ’ . ‘ Bealach a ’ Sgail is on the way from Uig in Lewis to North Harris , and is still sometimes used by people doing the journey on foot . It was the regular route in the days before modern means of communication ’ .

1315 , 1344 , luaidh .
Rather ‘ If I heard of another girl being mentioned in connection with you ’ ‘ being matched with you ’ .

and translated literally .

The expression Na h - eòin - mhóra was translated ‘ the Great Auks ’ by Alexander Carmichael in a St . Kilda song quoted in his ‘ Grazing and Agrestic Customs of the Outer Hebrides ’ printed in Appendix A of the Report of the Crofters ’ Commission , p . 467 ( 1883 ) .
